title: Why is Machu Picchu called that? What does it mean? - Quora

response.answer_text: Machu Picchu is a Quechua word that means “Old Mountain” or “Old Peak.” Broken down Machu means old or ancient and Picchu means peak. In contrast, the mountain that sits across from it called Huayna Picchu can be translated from Quechua to “Young Peak.” Machu Picchu is an important archaeological site and was a very important spiritual site for the Inca Empire. It was so important that only the Inca Royalty lived at Machu Picchu while the Quechua common-folk would hike to the city to farm it. Additionally, Machu Picchu was an important spiritual site for the Inca. For example, an arrow-shaped stone at the top of Huayna Picchu points directly through the Intihautana Stone to Mount Salcantay, which was one of the most important mountains in Inca cosmology. For any other Machu Picchu facts that may interest you, be sure to check out 50 Unbelievable Machu Picchu Facts.

Machu Picchu, or Macchu Pikchu is called as such because of its Spanish originations as machu meaning old, old person and pikchu meaning peak; mountain or prominence with a broad base which ends in sharp peaks and hence, "old peak".
